div.head: Compositional Methods in the Early Manuscripts
div.p: W. G. Collingwood, the first editor to examine the early manuscripts systematically, concluded that Ruskinʼs compositional abilities in youth were effortless, especially the boy's composition in verse: “invention and versification . . . were apparently spontaneous, and—to judge from the comparatively small amount of interlineation—almost improvisational” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1: 261; Poems [8o, 1891], 1: 262). The facility of Ruskin's poetic composition was remarked likewise during his youth--for example, by his father, John James Ruskin, in an 1834 letter to James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835), commenting on the rapidity and prolificacy of the verse writing. These qualities combined with lack of originality appear to have been viewed as characteristic of the precocious youthful writer. At the same time, no negative impression attached to what the Ruskins described as the ease of John's writing: "I do not like to check or point out faults," Ruskin's mother, Margaret, wrote to her husband at an early stage of John's practice as a writer, "lest I might make that a labour which is at present done with perfect ease & delight." She deferred to John's "talent of writing letters with astonishing ease" as a trait shared between father to son, with John inheriting the ability "of expressing all he wishes on paper with all his papas superiority" cementing the bonds of the family, and representing an openness among them. Margaret therefore "let Johns letters come just as he writes them," she told her husband, "that you may not be misled in your judgment as to his hopes and feelings" (letters of 14 February and 4 March 1829, Ruskin Family Letters, 176, 185).

There is no trace of subsequent revision on the author's part of any poems, except those which actually appeared in print during his youth." Poetic . The extent of revision in fact varies among extant drafts of various works, and we can rarely determine with certainty whether an earliest available extant draft represents an initial state of composition--a state that may have reflected more complex decisions than the apparently spontaneous flow of text in extant drafts.Interlineation is not so uncommon as Collingwoodʼs remarks suggests; and the editors of the Library Edition, who were more interested than Collingwood in genetic text, took issue with this generalization (Ruskin, Works, 2:529 n. 2). Collingwood does, however, make an apt distinction between the extent of revision in differing works. For most of Ruskinʼs poems, he asserts, the surviving rough draft may be “difficult to read” and—since “a single poem was often composed in fragments, at different times, interspersed between all sorts of other writings”—appear “chaotic” at first glance. Nonetheless, the confused appearance arises from Ruskinʼs spontaneous method and not revision. “There is no trace of subsequent revision on the authorʼs part of any poems, except those which actually appeared in print during his youth” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:261; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:262). The caveat is important. While it is certainly an exaggeration to deny categorically that Ruskin revised, except when faced with publication, it is nonetheless a valuable observation that he tended to revise extensively only when prodded to so by the prospect of seeing his work in print. Most other works exhibit relatively minor (if sometimes revealing) differences between draft and fair copy. What this may suggest is not that Ruskin resisted changing ideas, but that, in his spontaneity, he preferred to explore new ideas by writing new works.

This hypothesis may explain a new procedure in the documentary witness of draft and fair copy that emerges in 18??. In that year, Ruskin started keeping notebooks for rough draft separately from notebooks for fair copy, MS VI and MS VIII being the prime examples of rough‐draft notebooks. Their purpose may have been less to alter given works than to spin out new ones, and there is some indication that he wished to explore those ideas privately. It is probably not a coincidence that the rough draft notebooks emerge when Ruskin was entering adolescence.

Prior to this time, Ruskin may have worked more or less directly in his Red Books without significant prior drafting. Separate drafts may of course now be lost or have existed only in temporary form, such as on an erasable slate, but E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn take too much for granted in asserting that, for example, the poems forming the MS I Poetry Anthology “were no doubt fair‐copied into the book from rough, if contemporary, drafts” (Ruskin, Works, 2:529). Evidence suggests that MS I was itself the place for both drafting and fair‐copying. Deletions and insertions become prominent only at the points when Ruskin transcribed text directly from a published source—a phenomenon that would have characterized copying from his own drafts, as well, had he done so—suggesting that, in the portions of text containing original composition, invention flowed easily, whereas copying was for him a mechanical business (see “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1: Composition and Publication). Moreover, in the same Red Book, some places reveal erasure of a text beneath the fair copy—text that is probably a variant of the fair copy—suggesting that Ruskin drafted and fair‐copied in the same document, perhaps without much change.

By contrast, MS VI and MS VIII, while certainly providing Ruskin with a space in which he could freely revise in the course of composition, are often less remarkable for variants in works that he fair‐copied elsewhere than for works that were expunged or removed altogether. MS VI is missing . ; and MS VIII contains works that have been carefully inked out . Of course, we have no way of knowing who expunged such works or tore out pages, or exactly when and why the obfuscations occurred. But an overall pattern is noticeable of composing, and sometimes disposing of new works, rather than heavily revising existing ones.

In keeping with this tendency, MS and MS VIII contain a great deal of fragmentary verse, often of such similar character that it is difficult to decide whether some fragments form segments of a single work—divided by other, intervening projects—or represent projects in themselves. To some degree, if one reads these notebooks as ongoing explorations of ideas and emotions, the distinction is less interesting than their sequential unfolding; and even at those points when Ruskin identifiably shifts between different projects and genres, the segments can be as profitably examined in the emotional and thematic context of the surrounding fragments as in the implied context of the forming, unitary work.

It is revealing that the Sermon Books, which Ruskin worked on at the same time that MS VI and MS VIII , to some extent revert to his apparent earlier practice in the Red Books of fair‐copying over top of draft .

Collingwoodʼs caveat that extensive revision does characterize poems that “actually appeared in print during [Ruskinʼs] youth” applies even to his first published work, “On Skiddaw and Derwentwater,” a birthday poem for his father that Ruskin revised for publication in the Spiritual Times , a journal edited by his tutor, Edward Andrews . (It may have been the experience of revising this work for publication that prodded Ruskin into the practice of separating notebooks for drafting and for fair‐copying.) MS II, in which Ruskin both initially drafted and subsequently revised the poem, is a hybrid document, entitled “Works” by Ruskin as if holding the same status as the Red Books, but containing what appear meant as fair copies along with the draft for “On Skiddaw and Derwentwater.” It is also the first manuscript to present a version .
